POR.DRECONTENT:
The award 1004646 was given with the aim of investigating various topics in Differential Geometry and Geometric Analysis. Specifically, the PI intended to developed parts of the theory of mathematical objections known as minimal surfaces. Minimal surfaces arise naturally as soap films, as well as many other scientific contexts and have found diverse applications from nanotechnology to computer vision. The PI was at the outset of the award principally interested in minimal surfaces in their relation to a non-linear diffusion equation known as Mean Curvature Flow and the closely related Ricci flow, used by Perelman in his recent proof of the Poincare Conjecture. Mean Curvature Flow and a modification of the Ricci flow belong to an extremely important class of evolution equations known as gradient flows, which have the property that they optimize a given quantity (such as energy or area) most efficiently. This maximal effiiencey arises time and again in our physical universe, and precise understanding of such processes are thus crucially important for many technical context. Since the beginning of the study of Mean Curvature Flow in the early 1980's, it was known that "singularities"--places where the law governing the evolution break down--almost alway occur and are modeled by minimal surfaces, and understanding the nature of these breakdowns as been a central focus of various groups of mathematicians ever since. One of the main results of the PI and his collaborators during the tenure of the award has been the construction of infinitely many geometrically distinct singularities for the Mean Curvature Flow, when previously only 4 were known to exist. Since the beginning of the award, the objectives of the PI have broadened considerably, and we are presently working on enhancing certain computational aspects of our proof and our techique generally. Specifically, we are trying translate our results into the language of Domain Decomposition Methods, which are frequently used in the applied sciences for there rapid and efficient approximation by computers.
